questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Paracusis Willisii means the patient can hear better in noisy surroundings than in quiet surroundings.
  • This is because a normal person will raise their voice in noisy surroundings.
  • This is a characteristic feature of otospongiosis(Otosclerosis) and is seen only in this condition(Other options ruled out).

Otosclerosis:

  • Otosclerosis, more aptly called otospongiosis, is a primary disease of the bony labyrinth.
  • In this, one or more foci of irregularly laid spongy bone replace part of the normally dense endochondral layer of the bony otic capsule.
  • Most often, otosclerotic focus involves the stapes region, leading to stapes fixation and conductive deafness.
  • However, it may involve certain other areas of the bony labyrinth where it may cause neurosensory loss or no symptoms at all.

Symptoms:

  • Hearing loss
  • Tinnitus
  • Paracusis Willisii
  • Vertigo

Signs:

  • Schwartz sign(Reddish hue on the tympanic membrane) indicates an active lesion and is a contraindication to the surgery.
  • Rinne's test will be negative, and Weber will be lateralized to the ear with more conductive loss.
  • Gelle's test will not show any change in BC.
  • PTA shows Carhart's notch at 2000 Hz
  • The Blue Mantle sign is seen in histology.

Treatment:

  • Medical- Sodium Fluoride to decrease the activity of the active focus.
  • Surgical- Stapedotomy using a Teflon or Stainless steel piston.

questions.text: Which tuning fork test is specifically used to diagnose otosclerosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gelle's Test:

  • It's a special tuning fork test used to diagnose otosclerosis.
  • In normal people, bone conduction is decreased with Seigelisation due to tightening of the ossicular assembly with Seigelisation.
  • In otosclerosis, the system is already tight, so there is no change in BC sound.

Explanation of other topics:

Stenger test(Option A): Used to detect unilateral non-organic (functional) hearing loss.

Schwabach test(Option B): Compares the patient's bone conduction to the examiner's; detects sensorineural vs conductive hearing loss, but is not specific for otosclerosis.

Rinne test(Option D): Compares air conduction vs bone conduction, used broadly for conductive vs sensorineural hearing loss, but not specific for otosclerosis.

questions.text: A 31-year-old female patient complains of bilateral impairment of hearing for the past 5 years. The audiogram shows bilateral conductive deafness. Impedance audiometry shows As type of curve. All constitute part of the treatment, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Steroids are never used as a treatment for Otosclerosis. Hence, doesn't constitute part of the treatment.
  • The history and investigations done suggest the diagnosis of Otosclerosis.
  • A type of curve in the tympanogram is seen in Otosclerosis or Tympanosclerosis.

Treatment:

The Rx of choice is surgery called Stapedotomy>Stapedectomy. (Option C ruled out)

Other treatments for Otosclerosis.

  • A hearing aid is given to patients unwilling to undergo surgery. (Option A ruled out)
  • Sodium fluoride (NaF) oral therapy. It is a treatment of choice for(Option B ruled out).
    • a. Schwartz sign (+) patient. (Early stage of disease)
    • b. Cochlear otosclerosis
  • NaF leads to stabilisation of the disease. It is contraindicated in Chronic nephritis, Fluorosis, in pregnant and lactating women and children.
  • NaF acts as an Inhibitor of osteoclast activity and so a stabiliser of bone turnover.

questions.text: Phelp's sign on CECT Head is typically seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Glomus Jugulare tumours are paragangliomas that arise in the jugular foramen and are highly vascular, hence they enhance vividly on contrast imaging, leading to the Phelp sign.
  • The phelp sign is defined as erosion of the bony septum between the carotid canal and the jugular foramen.
  • It erodes the floor of the middle ear and starts growing in the Hypotympanum as a red vascular mass(Rising sun sign).

Explanation of other options:

Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma)(Option B):

  • Arises from the vestibular nerve in the cerebellopontine angle
  • Typically shows moderate enhancement, not intensely vascular
  • Not associated with Phelps' sign

Sigmoid Sinus Thrombosis(Option C):

  • Non-enhancing filling defect in the sigmoid sinus
  • Not a vascular tumour, no Phelps' sign

Cerebellopontine Angle Meningioma(Option D):

  • Shows uniform enhancement but is less vascular than glomus tumours
  • Again, not associated with Phelps' sign.

questions.text: Reena, a 43-year-old, presents to the clinic with a pulsatile mass in the ear that bleeds heavily on touching. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • These are classic features of a Glomus tumour, particularly Glomus tympanicum or Glomus jugulare, which are highly vascular paragangliomas located in the middle ear or jugular foramen region.
  • The other three options are non-pulsatile and do not arise from the vascular system(Other options ruled out).

Glomus Jugulare:

  • It is a type of Paraganglioma like that of the Pheochromocytoma, and 10% can be secretory.
  • They secrete catecholamines, so 24-hour urinary VMA (Vanillylmandelic acid) levels are checked in Glomus Jugulare also.
  • It is a most common benign non-capsulated locally invasive highly vascular tumour of the middle ear.
  • It is more common in females.
  • Site of origin- it arises from glomus cells lying around the jugular bulb, involving the 9th and 10th cranial nerves.
  • It is a skull-based jugular foramen tumour.

Spread of the tumour:

  • The red vascular tumour erodes the floor of the middle ear and grows into the hypotympanum
  • This is called the Rising Sun sign.
  • The tumour now erodes the tympanic membrane and grows into the external auditory canal, leading to a bleeding ear.
  • The tumour eventually erodes the wall of the middle ear and enters the mastoid area.
  • At the skull base, it is a Jugular foramen tumour. This tumour will erode the bony septum between the carotid canal and jugular foramen. This finding on CT scans is called the Phelp sign.
  • Later, the tumour will have an intracranial extension.
  • 4% of this tumour can lead to metastasis.
  • It is a jugular foramen tumour. Hence, the involvement of 9,10,11 nerves is common.
  • Facial nerve involvement can also be seen.

Fisch staging-4 Types (A, B, C, D):

A. The tumour is limited to the middle ear.

B. Middle ear + mastoid

C. Carotid canal

D. Intracranial extension

Chief Complaints:

  • Female patient with pulsatile tinnitus. This tinnitus is synchronous with the pulse.
  • Bleeding red pulsatile ear mass.
  • Hearing loss-CHL - Rinne-ve

Examination -

  • RISING SUN SIGN.
  • Red ear mass blanches on selegiline. This is called the Brown sign.
  • Pulsatile mass in the ear, these Pulsations will disappear on pressing the carotid arteries. This is called the Aquino sign.

Investigations:

  • Biopsy is contraindicated.
  • PTA shows CHL mostly.
  • A CT scan will show the Phelp sign. It is the erosion of the bony septum between the carotid canal and the Jugular Foramen.
  • MRI to rule out intracranial extension.
  • MR Angiography - to find out the main source of blood supply for this tumour.
  • The most common blood supply to this tumour is the ascending pharyngeal artery, and pre-operative embolisation will reduce blood loss during surgery.

Treatment-

  • The Rx of choice is surgery. Gamma knife therapy is 2ndoption, if the spread is limited.

Key takeaways:

Glomus tumours are of two types :

  • Glomus Jugularae-This arises from the glomus cells of the jugular bulb.
  • Glomus Tympanicum-This arises from the glomus cells of the tympanic plexus in the It presents as a reddish mass behind the tympanic membrane with pulsatile tinnitus and CHL.

questions.text: You are an ENT resident. A patient presents to you with a pulsatile mass in the ear that bleeds on touching. You suspect it to be a glomus tumour. How will you decide if it is glomus tympanicum or glomus jugulare?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT scan) of the temporal bone is the best imaging modality to define bony anatomy and erosion patterns, assess the extent of the tumour and differentiate glomus tympanicum (limited to the middle ear) vs glomus jugulare (involves jugular foramen, causes bone erosion).
